Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my mother’s voice echoing in my mind as she explained how important it was for me to lead the family ceremony this year. “It’s your turn,” she said, her eyes shining with pride and expectation. I knew how much this meant to her, to all of us—keeping our traditions alive, showing respect for our heritage. I wanted to make her proud, to honor everything my family stood for.

Just as I was rehearsing the opening lines, my phone buzzed. It was Mia, my closest friend. Her voice trembled, barely holding back tears. “Can you talk? I really need you right now,” she whispered. I could hear the pain in her words, the kind that only a friend could help soothe. She needed me to listen, to be there for her, just as I always promised I would.

My heart pounded as I stared at the family altar, then at my phone. Both worlds pulled at me, each expecting my full attention, each unwilling to wait. I felt torn, the weight of tradition pressing on one side, the urgency of friendship on the other, unsure which part of me should answer first.
